Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of a Focused Ion Beam - Scanning Electron Microscope (FIB-SEM) for Nano/Micro Fabrication/Characterization

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

"This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5)"

University of Massachusetts at Lowell (UML) requests support for the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Auriga CrossBeam Focused Ion Beam - Scanning Electron Microscope (FIB-SEM) workstation from Carl Zeiss for research and research training that are critical for workforce training and regional economic development.
Intellectual Merit: Complemented with existing extensive resources, the FIB-SEM can simultaneously perform machining and characterization of both conductive and nonconductive materials with best-in-class resolution. It will enable in-depth, fundamental research and position UML among the leaders in nanomanufacturing and plastics engineering research. While a few ongoing research projects will benefit from the requested system, several new programs that have been hindered by this lacking capability will be initiated. In addition, the acquisition will strengthen UML?s fast-growing research areas in nanomedicine, biomedical devices, and bioengineering. Last but not the least, collaborations with nearby universities and local companies will be enhanced. Examples include tooling for cost-effective nanomanufacturing systems, high speed AFM tip arrays for high-rate nanomanufacturing, and nanoparticle drug delivery systems.
Broader Impacts: The requested equipment will immediately impact research by more than 20 faculty members from nine departments. Graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students as well as industry professionals will benefit from programs incorporating the FIB system. A unique "machining" program will be piloted with the Nashoba Valley Technical High School and extended to local technical high schools. In addition, UML has long-standing ties with industry and flexible arrangements for equipment use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary  

University of Massachusetts Lowell (UML) requested support for the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Auriga CrossBeam Focused Ion Beam - Scanning Electron Microscope (FIB-SEM) workstation from Carl Zeiss for research and education in fabrication and characterization of nanoscale tooling. The system is equipped with a Gemini electron beam column, a Cobra focused liquid metal ion source and column, a Leica cryo-stage and sputter coating system, an Omniprobe 4-axis nanomanipulator, a multi-gas injection system and various electron and ion detectors.

Intellectual Merit:
Complemented with existing extensive resources, the FIB-SEM can simultaneously perform machining and characterization of both conductive and nonconductive materials with best-in-class resolution. It enabled in-depth, fundamental research and position UML among the leaders in  nanomanufacturing and plastics engineering research. While a few ongoing research projects benefited from the system, several new programs that have been hindered by this lacking capability were initiated. In addition, the acquisition strengthened UML’s fast-growing research areas in nanomedicine, biomedical devices, and bioengineering. Last
but not least, collaborations with other universities and local companies were enhanced. Examples include nanofabrication of polymer-derived ceramics for high temperature sensing components under collaboration with University of Central Florida; sample preparation of photovoltaic devices under collaboration with University of Massachusetts Amherst; and failure analysis of Anisotropic Magneto-Resistive (AMR) devices for MEMSIC Company. 

Preparation & Location:
Site preparation for the instrument which was completed in early January 2011 involved the renovation of an existing room within the Materials
Characterization Laboratory (MCL) located in Olney Science Center at UML. Service engineers from Carl Zeiss, Leica Microsystems and Omniprobe worked collaboratively to undertake the installation and performance testing of the FIB-SEM workstation including the Leica cryo-stage, the Leica sputter coating system, and the Omniprobe nanomanipulator. Final installations and performance checkout were completed during the first week of April 2011. In August 2013, the FIB-SEM System was moved into the Mark and Elisia Saab Emerging Technologies and Innovation Center (ETIC), a new 84,000 sq.ft, $80 million dollar research facility opened in October 2012. This move expanded the utility of the FIB-SEM by locating it next to the clean room facility and characterization area in the ETIC. 

Training & Staff Assistance:
Using his previous instrumental teaching experience, Christopher Santeufemio is establishing a comprehensive user training program to provide users with the basic operational skills to efficiently use the instrument and to protect the instrument from abuse or misuse. The training program consists of a minimum of one two-hour group session and three two-hour individual hands-on sessions emphasizing theoretical and practical aspects of operating the ion milling, deposition and imaging functions of the FIB-SEM. Specific safety issues were also discussed. Users must pass a one two-hour accreditation test to demonstrate their competency before access to the FIB-SEM is granted. In addition, UML can send users to Peabody (U.S. Headquarters of Zeiss) for applications help. 

Broader Impacts:  The Auriga FIB-SEM system greatly enhanced UML’s ability to perform cutting-edge cross-disciplinary research by facilitating fabrication of tooling and devices as well as characterization for a wide range of polymeric and biological systems....
